journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Downwards inference: Bayesian analysis of overlapping higher-level data sets of complex binary-state on-demand systems

contrib-group.aff: Center for Risk and Reliability, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Center for Risk and Reliability, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA. email: chris_jackson79@hotmail.com

abstract.p: A developed Bayesian approach for generating inference from multiple overlapping higher level data sets on component failure probabilities within complex on-demand systems is presented in this paper. Data sets are overlapping if they are drawn from the same process or system at the same time. Alternate methodologies are typically strictly limited to analyzing non-overlapping data, which can both lose or incorrectly infer information if the data is overlapping in nature. The methodology outlined in this paper is based on typical understanding of system logic represented using fault-trees, reliability block diagrams or another equivalent representation. Structure functions of the system at relevant sensor locations (developed from the system logic) in terms of component states are used in conjunction with the probability of all possible system states (or all possible state vectors) to generate the likelihood function of overlapping evidence. This forms the basis of the likelihood function used in the Bayesian analysis of the overlapping data sets.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Current system reliability analysis methodologies focus on using system failure logic (such as that represented in reliability block diagrams or fault-trees) to express system failure probability based on the failure probabilities of subordinate components. For example, the Nuclear Regulatory Committee (NRC) Probability Risk Assessment Guide breaks this process into defining component failure probabilities, determining system minimal cut-set probabilities and using them to quantify system reliability [1]. This procedure is replicated in many other relevant textbooks and handbooks.

An observation of these techniques is that the system reliability is considered a function of component reliabilities. This has shaped the methodology of system reliability analysis by focusing reliability testing to the component level and then calculating system-level reliability estimates thereafter. This approach automatically precludes useful system and sub-system data (which is referred to as higher level data as it appears ‘higher’ in many visualization methodologies).

Reliability analysis inherently involves the ‘downwards’ propagation of information. A component can be tested and information inferred ‘down’ into the underlying parameters that define reliability characteristics (the term ‘down’ is used as it is common for systems to be represented hierarchically with parameters at the bottom of visualization methodologies, systemic level at the top and sub-systems and components in between). Reliability prediction inherently involves ‘upwards’ propagation of information, as the parameters determined during analysis are then used through reliability models and system logic to calculate component and system level reliability performance. Downwards propagation is more difficult to conduct as part of reliability analysis, and minimal methodologies exist for it to be conducted beyond basic component levels.

Because system reliability is a function of component reliabilities, the incorporation of higher level data infers information about component reliability parameters. The function that generates system reliability based on component reliabilities is generally not invertible (i.e. although it is possible to generate an exact system reliability for a given set of component reliabilities, there is generally no unique set of component reliabilities for a given system reliability). The effect of this is to reduce the amount of inferable information.

Jackson and Mosleh first introduced a Bayesian methodology to incorporate overlapping data of on-demand systems [2]. On-demand systems are those that are subject to discrete demands or trials and will respond by operating (or existing) within certain discrete states. Binary-state on-demand systems have only two such states: failure and success. By definition, on-demand systems are made up of on-demand components that also operate in discrete states (noting that the maximum number of states each component can exist in is the number of system level states). The state that an on-demand system or component exists in is a discrete random variable. The probability of the state of an on-demand system is a function of the component state probabilities, dictated by the system structure or logic.

Continuous time-based systems and components differ from their on-demand counterparts in that the probability that they exist in a particular state (or transition from one state to another) is a function of time. The time at which a component or system transitions from one state to another is a continuous random variable. Hybrid systems involve both on-demand and continuous time-based components.

This paper examines all previous methodologies and develops those proposed by Jackson and Mosleh for complex systems. The methodology in this paper is illustrated through examples involving simple systems, but is scalable and equally applicable to complex systems.

sec.title: 2 Current Methodologies
sec.p: Higher-level data are typically gathered by sensors placed throughout the system structure. Typically, a sensor always exists at the system level (as in system level failure can be immediately observed or detected), however it may be desirable to place sensors elsewhere in the system to gather more diagnostic information. Each sensor does not form part of the system function, but can detect whether the system is functional at that point. Sensors are most applicable for sub-systems with their own functionality, and hence failure more easily detec-ted. This concept is explored further below.

An approximate Bayesian method was considered through reliability block diagram methodology that combined system and component level data by Mastran and Singpurwalla [3]. A top-down approach combined system level data with component level data and prior distributions to update component life characteristics, which in turn provides a posterior distribution of system reliability.

An alternate approximate Bayesian procedure based on a bottom-up approach with prior distribution parameters which were then combined with data was developed by Martz et al. [4] and Martz and Waller [5].

Fully Bayesian techniques have previously been developed [6, 7]. The latter technique involves beta prior distributions at the component level to incorporate test data of the form of k failures out of r demands to generate posterior component distributions. This allows both upwards and downwards propagation of information but cannot incorporate overlapping data. A multi-state technique was developed by Graves et al. [8] also based on fault-tree systemic representation. The Hamada et al. method is written formally as

where p~n is the set of n component failure probabilities {p1, p2, p3, …, pj, …, pn}, pS is a system or sub-system failure probability expressed as functions of p~n, m is the number of system and sub-system probabilities under consideration, the prior beta distributions of component failure probabilities have parameters α and β, and evidence is input as shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Expression of system level evidence for the Hamada et al. method

sec.p: The resultant equation is

For the Hamada et al. method, it can be seen that all evidence must be of the form of k detected failures out of r demands. An example of an application of the method of Hamada et al. for a basic system is illustrated in Example 1.

The Hamada et al. method is computationally efficient to evaluate and should be used in scenarios involving non-overlapping data binary on-demand systems. The techniques outlined in this paper are designed to incorporate both overlapping and non-overlapping data, but are more computationally intensive. A discussion on the differences between overlapping and non-overlapping data, including their implications, is included below.

Example 1. The system level failure probability of the basic two component on demand series system depicted in Fig. 1 (or the probability of failure detection by sensor #1), pS1, is defined in terms of the failure probabilities of components 1 and 2, (p1 and p2 respectively).
The system is subjected to two tests.
Test 1: A series of 10 demands where 10 system level failures were detected by sensor #1 (sensor #2 was not involved).
Test 2: A series of 10 demands where 10 failures were detected at the system level and one failure was detected by sensor #2.
Assuming uniform prior distributions and using the Hamada et al. method, respective posterior distributions of component failure probabilities are illustrated in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Joint posterior distribution of p1 and p2

sec.p: It can be seen that, from test 1, the failure probabilities of p1 and p2 are likely to be high (i.e. close to 1). This makes conceptual sense, as it is known that the system has a high failure probability and systemic failure in test 1 occurs whenever component 1 or 2 fails. Alternately, it can be seen from test 2 that component 1 has a low failure probability given that it failed once in 10 demands. This correctly implies that component 2 must therefore have a very high failure probability to generate the high system level failure probability.

sec.title: 3 Overlapping Data
sec.p: Sets of overlapping data need to meet the following criteria.

list-item.p: Simultaneity: the data sets are drawn from observations or demands that occur at the same time; and
Correspondence: the data sets are resultant from the same system or process.

sec.p: It is often the case that higher-level data sets that are used to assess lower-level parameters of systems will be overlapping or dependent in nature (for instance, if the data are derived at various component, sub-system and assembly levels from the same system at the same time). Furthermore, there may be relationships between higher-level data and multiple manifestations of the same lower-level parameter. Such instances demand special consi-derations and concepts to be developed in order to fully capture all aspects of available information. The system described in Example 1 involves overlapping data, as the system-level data set is affected by the sensor #2 data set (correspondence) and the data are gathered from each sensor at the same time or demand (simultaneity), although that relationship was not explored.

For analysis methodologies that treat overlapping data as non-overlapping, the dependence between lower- and higher-level data sets is ignored. Each set of overlapping data is dependent on all other data sets. Conversely, non-overlapping datasets are not influenced by any other data set. If component 1 of the system in Example 1 is tested separately after the completion of the system level test, the reliability data obtained for the entire system and component 1 is non-overlapping as they were not observed at the same time (non-simultaneity), even though the data was from the same system or process (correspondence).

Having some information about component failure probabilities can influence overall system reliability analysis. Non-overlapping data is significant in the field of reliability analysis of systems as it is not uncommon for data to be gathered simultaneously at multiple levels from the same system.

sec.title: 4 Treatment of Non-Overlapping and Overlapping Data in Bayes’ Theorem
sec.p: The method proposed by Jackson and Mosleh, is explored here. Bayes’ theorem is written formally as

where θ is the set of unknowns of interest or parameters, π0(θ) is the prior distribution of θ representing the initial state of knowledge, L(E|θ) is the likelihood of observing a set of evidence, E, for a given θ, and π1(θ|E) is the updated posterior distribution of the set of unknowns of interest or parameters representing the updated state of knowledge.

list-item.p: Non-overlapping data. Non-overlapping data sets are ‘observationally’ independent and therefore generate independent likelihood functions. In the context of a complex system where the set of n component failure probabilities p~n = {p1, p2, p3, …, pn}, Bayes’ theorem is written as
where {E1, E2, E3, …} is a number of non-overlapping data/evidence sets.

Overlapping data. The likelihood functions for overlapping data are interdependent, and cannot be substituted into equation. They generate one encompassing likelihood function. Over-lapping data is represented formally in Bayes’ theorem as
where {E1•,E2•,E3•,...} is a number of overlapping data/evidence sets.
As overlapping data sets are dependent, the overall likelihood function is not a product of individual data set likelihood functions

sec.title: 5 Likelihood Function of Overlapping Data from Complex On-Demand Systems
sec.p: To develop the overlapping data likelihood function, permutations of possible instances of component failures (and the probability of each permutation) need to be developed. The probability (or likelihood) of each permutation can then be substituted into equation. This is achieved in three steps.

list-item.p: State vector analysis. All possible permutations of state variables for each component need to be analysed. The state variable for the jth component is denoted xj, which is defined as
The state of all components in the entire system can be defined by the state vector
As there are multiple possible state vectors, the lth state vector (and its constituent component state variables) is written as

Structure functions. Structure functions calculate the state of the system at sensor locations (i.e. at sub-system and system levels) based on the state vector. The structure function equates to 0 if the relevant sensor’s (sub-) system is functional and 1 if it has failed. Many structure functions are used where ‘1’ denotes functionality and ‘0’ denotes failure. For ease of future calculation, the structure functions used in this paper are effectively reversed so that they generate system state variables.

As each component state is binary, there will be 2n permutations and hence 2n possible state vectors. The probability of each state vector occurring can be calculated based on individual component failure probabilities, pj

(Sub-)System failure combinations. The third step is to develop multiple sets of combinations of r state vectors (recalling that r refers to the number of systemic demands in the data set) such that each combination generates the same number of detected failures as the evidence set, E = {kS1, kS2, …, kSm, r}. It is important to note that the evidence set involves aggregates of failure detections for each sensor after r demands
where vl is the number of occurrences of the lth state vector, xln.
The ath combination is written as

sec.p: where (vl)a is the number of occurrences of the lth state vector in the ath combination, ca. The probability of the ath combination of state vectors, ca, occurring given a set of lower level component failure probabilities is
(this is simply a specific instance of the multinomial distribution)
substituting (11) yields
Since each state vector is linked with a specific demand, the total number of state vectors in the combination must sum to r
Each different combination implies a different number of failures detected by each sensor. The number of failures detected by the ith sensor is given as

If the ath combination of state vectors, ca, implies the evidence set E = {kS1, kS2, …, kSm, r} and is part of the set CE. For this to occur, the number of failures implied by ca that are detected by each sensor must equal the number of detected failures in the evidence set, that is
The likelihood function is the probability of observing the evidence, E, for a given instance of p~n = {p1, p2, …, pj, …, pn}. The likelihood function is developed as
substituting (14) yields
Therefore, for a complex system with single occurrences of each component

sec.title: 6 Comparison with the Hamada et al. Method
sec.p: The Hamada et al. method cannot incorporate information inherent in overlapping data sets by treating them as non-overlapping. The level of dependence between each element of the data/evidence set contextualizes all others. This dependence can then be exploited to more thoroughly understand the system using the downwards inference technique. Non-overlapping data contains no such dependence, and therefore there is no context between elements of the data/evidence set.
Example 2. Consider the basic two component series system examined in Example 1 that was subjected to the second test regime. The structure functions for the system at each sensor location are

Since there are two components (that is n = 2), the number of possible state vectors is 2n = 22 = 4. The state vectors are listed in Table 2, along with the states detected by sensors that they imply and their inherent probabilities.

caption.p: State vectors of system in Fig. 1

sec.p: Since there are 10 demands (that is r = 10) there are 286 possible state vector combinations, c, as each demand will invoke one of the 4 possible state vectors. A truncated list of combinations is shown in Table 3, along with the implied states detected by all sensors. There are only two possible combinations that imply the evidence.

caption.p: Possible state vector combinations of system in Fig. 1

tr.th: State vector combination, Ca(no. of lth state vectors)

sec.p: The normalized likelihood function given by equation is substituted into equation with uniform prior distributions to generate the posterior distribution plotted in Fig. 3, along with the posterior distribution derived by the Hamada et al. method. The normalized percentage error of the Hamada et al. method is illustrated in Fig. 4.

caption.p: Joint posterior distributions of p1 and p2 from Test 2 evidence
Percentage error in non-overlapping data likelihood function (maximum error = 3.55 per cent)

sec.p: The two posterior distributions in Fig. 3 are approximately equal, with the normalized Hamada et al. (non-overlapping) posterior distribution dif-fering by no more than 3.55 per cent from the over-lapping data posterior distribution. This good approximation is due to the nature of the evidence, E. The inference of the system level data contains a relatively small ‘observational’ dependence on the inference of the sensor #2 data.
Example 3 illustrates the potential effect for an evidence set that contains a significant dependence between the data levels.
Example 3. The basic two-component series system examined in Example 1 and
Example 2 subjected to a third test regime.
Test 3: A series of ten demands where five system level failures were detected by sensor #1 and five failures were detected by sensor #2.
The evidence can be interpreted in two separate ways:

list-item.p: Overlapping data. The implication of evidence set E is illustrated in Fig. 5. In effect, component 1 has been observed to fail five times on ten demands and component 2 has been observed to fail zero times on five demands.

Non-overlapping data. The implication of evidence set E is illustrated in Fig. 6. In effect, component 1 has been observed to fail five times on ten demands whilst the system has separately been observed to fail another five times on ten demands. This introduces additional uncertainty on both components, and will imply that component 2 has a higher likelihood of having a high failure probability.

sec.p: The normalized likelihood function given by equation is substituted into equation with uniform prior distributions to generate a posterior distribution plotted in Fig. 7, along with the posterior distribution derived by the Hamada et al. method.

caption.p: Joint posterior distributions of p1 and p2 from test 3 evidence

sec.p: The error associated with treating overlapping data as non-overlapping (i.e. the difference between the two graphs in Fig. 7) are illustrated in Fig. 8.

caption.p: Percentage error in non-overlapping data likelihood function (maximum error = 59.97 per cent)

sec.p: Higher-level data may become effectively redundant in the context of lower-level data, which may mask information about some components. Treating the data as non-overlapping may incorrectly imply information about these components in such instances. When there is only one data set (as in data is gathered from only one sensor), the data cannot be considered to be overlapping or non-overlapping. In this case, the Hamada et al. and overlapping data methods generate identical likelihood functions.

sec.title: 7 Multiple Instances of Identical Components – Inference Diagrams
sec.p: Multiple occurrences of identical components are incorporated into the likelihood function using state of knowledge dependence. The underlying failure probability of each identical component (i.e. same component type) is the same, and modifies the likelihood function accordingly. The unknown of interest, p~n, then becomes the set of component type failure probabilities where n is the number of component types. In this construct, the total number of components is denoted n′ (and therefore n ≤ n′). The component types are numbered 1, 2, 3, …, j, …, n, and the components are numbered 1, 2, 3, …, b, …, n′. The component type of the jth component is denoted jb. For a complex system with multiple occurrences of the same component

where the unknown of interest, p~n = {p1, p2, …, pj, …, pn} is the set of n lower-level component type failure probabilities, pjb is the failure probability of the bth component (which is the failure probability of jbth component type), ca is the ath combination of r state vectors (each state vector comprises of n′ component states), (vl)a is the number of occurrences of the lth state vector in ca and (xb)l is the state variable of the bth component in the lth state vector.

The different colours in the four-component, three-sensor system depicted in Fig. 9 denote different regions of inference and influence for each sensor. Components 2 and 3 are identical components (i.e. components from the same component type).The component type number of the jth component, jb, is listed in Table 4.

caption.p: Three-sensor on demand system with paths of apparent influence indicated
Component numbers and component type numbers for components in the system illustrated in Figure 9

sec.p: It can be seen that there are three distinct apparent inference paths. The blue inference path terminates at the top event or system level, and shows that components 1, 2 and sensor #3 do not have an apparent influence on system level characteristics since sensor #2 summarizes all subordinate structural characteristics. Should sensor #3 evidence change or be re-evaluated, it will have no implication on system level evidence if the sensor #2 evidence remains unchanged. In this way, sensors can isolate the inference and influence of subordinate systems, sub-systems and components. In effect, the inference of each sensor separate the system in Fig. 9 into three separate sub-systems as illustrated in Fig. 10.

caption.p: Three apparent sub-systems based on inference relationships

sec.p: Figure 9 introduces a specific type of diagram; specifically an inference diagram. It is a directed acyclic graph that illustrates paths of apparent inference and how sensor data summarizes the effect that subordinate components have on superior sensors. Inference diagrams are technically a form of an influence diagram primarily emanating from the fields of Bayesian networks and decision-making methodologies. Nevertheless, some distinction bet-ween the two is worthwhile as inference diagrams only involve events in the form of component functionality, and are meant to assign inference from components to sensors rather than being a fundamental part of calculation. They also include additional information on the nature of dependence between components by the inclusion of logical gates (such as the AND/OR gates of a fault-tree). The colour shading in Figs 9 and 10 emphasizes how the system is broken into sub-systems, while the grey shading highlights that components 2 and 3 both share failure probability p2, see [9].

In this way, the apparent inference from superior sensor data comes from subordinate sensor data and subordinate components. For example, components 3 and 4 in Figs 9 and 10 are subject to inference from sensors #1 and #2 only; how components 1 and 2 behave does not matter given data from sensor #2 is gathered (hence the term apparent inference).

The system in Fig. 9 is equally well represented by the three separate sub-systems in Fig. 10. By definition, these three sub-systems are overlapping through the dependency between failures detected by the same sensor represented in different sub-systems. However, the sub-systems can be treated as non-overlapping when each is calculated in the context of all other evidence sets (which would be the product of individual likelihood functions of each sub-system). As components 2 and 3 are identical but appear in different sub-systems, the likelihood of the component type failure probability is influenced by two of the three sub-system likelihood functions.

One of the strengths of the overlapping data likelihood function in equation is that it inherently accommodates all aspects of overlapping data and multiple occurrences of the same component through a state of knowledge dependency. This ability is due to the multinomial distribution which drives the overlapping data likelihood function. The multinomial distribution allows all possible combinations of component state variables and assigns correct probabilities for each. This results in a comprehensive likelihood function that is a true inference of all aspects of overlapping data.

sec.title: 8 Numerical Implementation
sec.p: The solution of the overlapping data likelihood function in equation is non-trivial and cannot easily be carried out by hand even for small systems requiring mathematical software for systems of moderate to high complexity. The speed of evaluation is largely dependent on the generation of possible state vectors for the system in question and then identifying all combinations of those state vectors that imply the evidence. There are multiple approaches in developing an algorithm that generates these combinations and the speed of this algorithm is linked to the complexity of the system. Once the state vector combinations are developed, the likelihood function is easily calculated.

It can be readily seen that the algorithm discussed in the paragraph above will not necessarily be simple or rapidly executed. It must be repeated here that should the data for analysis be non-overlapping in nature, the Hamada et al. method should be used to save computational time (in any event, the resultant likelihood function will be identical).

sec.title: 9 Discussion
sec.p: Although fully Bayesian methodologies have been developed to incorporate data at various levels within on-demand systems, the majority have been constrained to treat all data as non-overlapping. This ignores the dependencies between the data sets and effectively removes information inherent in data sets that are overlapping. An overlapping data likelihood function developed by Jackson and Mosleh [2] to incorporate these inherent dependencies and generate the correct inference within Bayes’ Theorem was developed and explored further. Several examples were developed to highlight the effect of the additional information overlapping data sets contain and how it can be used to correctly improve the state of knowledge (which is the set of component type failure probabilities). Additional examples were developed to demonstrate identical likelihood functions (for both overlapping and non-overlapping constructs) in the instance of one data set, which cannot be considered overlapping or non-overlapping due to its singularity. The flexibility of the likelihood function was also demonstrated to incorporate multiple instances of the same component simultaneously. Through state of knowledge dependence, the resultant overlapping data Bayesian method completely incorporates all information and evidence that can possibly be generated or observed by complex, on demand systems.

The evidence set examined in this paper, E = {kS1, kS2, …, kSm, r}, involves aggregates of failures detected at each sensor over r demands. It implies that the exact nature of sensor failure detections is not known (i.e. if failure was detected by each sensor at each demand). If possible, multiple evidence sets should not be combined into one aggregate set, as this represents a loss of information. For example, the evidence sets E1={kS11,kS21,...,kSm1,r1} and E2={kS12,kS22,...,kSm2,r2} should be separately analysed, and not combined to evidence set E={(kS11+kS12),(kS21+kS22),...,(kSm1+kSm2),(r1+r2)}.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: b The number of the component in question (1 ≤b≤n′).
c A combination of component state vectors: {v1, v2, v3, …, vl, …}.
ca The ath combination of component state vectors: {(v1)a, (v2)a, (v3)a, …, (vl)a, …}.
CE The set of all combinations of component state vectors that imply the evidence set E.
E Set of evidence (or data) that does not overlap with other evidence (or data) sets.
E• Set of evidence (or data) that overlaps with other evidence (or data) sets.
i The number of the sensor in question (1 ≤i≤m).
j The number of the component type in question (1 ≤j≤n).
jb The number of the component type of the bth component.
kj The number of failures of the jth component.
kSi The number of failures detected by the ith sensor.

n Number of component types in the system.
n′ Number of components in the system.
pj The jth component failure probability.
pSi The ith system or subsystem failure probability, or the probability of the ith sensor detecting failure (noting that each system and sub-system has a sensor detecting failure).

(vl)a The number of occurrences of the lth component state vector, xln, that appear in the ath combination of all possible component state vectors, ca.
